item.title: Run Llama 2 uncensored locally
item.description: This post will give some example comparisons running Llama 2 uncensored model versus its censored model.

item.title: Run Code Llama locally
item.description: Meta's Code Llama is now available on Ollama to try.

item.title: How to prompt Code Llama
item.description: This guide walks through the different ways to structure prompts for Code Llama and its different variations and features including instructions, code completion and fill-in-the-middle (FIM).

item.title: Leveraging LLMs in your Obsidian Notes
item.description: This post walks through how you could incorporate a local LLM using Ollama in Obsidian, or potentially any note taking tool.

item.title: Ollama is now available as an official Docker image
item.description: Ollama can now run with Docker Desktop on the Mac, and run inside Docker containers with GPU acceleration on Linux.

item.title: Building LLM-Powered Web Apps with Client-Side Technology
item.description: Recreate one of the most popular LangChain use-cases with open source, locally running software - a chain that performs Retrieval-Augmented Generation, or RAG for short, and allows you to “chat with your documents”

item.title: Python & JavaScript Libraries
item.description: The initial versions of the Ollama Python and JavaScript libraries are now available, making it easy to integrate your Python or JavaScript, or Typescript app with Ollama in a few lines of code. Both libraries include all the features of the Ollama REST API, are familiar in design, and compatible with new and previous versions of Ollama.

item.title: Vision models
item.description: New vision models are now available: LLaVA 1.6, in 7B, 13B and 34B parameter sizes. These models support higher resolution images, improved text recognition and logical reasoning.

item.title: OpenAI compatibility
item.description: Ollama now has initial compatibility with the OpenAI Chat Completions API, making it possible to use existing tooling built for OpenAI with local models via Ollama.

item.title: Windows preview
item.description: Ollama is now available on Windows in preview, making it possible to pull, run and create large language models in a new native Windows experience. Ollama on Windows includes built-in GPU acceleration, access to the full model library, and serves the Ollama API including OpenAI compatibility.

item.title: Ollama now supports AMD graphics cards
item.description: Ollama now supports AMD graphics cards in preview on Windows and Linux. All the features of Ollama can now be accelerated by AMD graphics cards on Ollama for Linux and Windows.

item.title: Embedding models
item.description: Embedding models are available in Ollama, making it easy to generate vector embeddings for use in search and retrieval augmented generation (RAG) applications.

item.title: Llama 3
item.description: Llama 3 is now available to run on Ollama. This model is the next generation of Meta's state-of-the-art large language model, and is the most capable openly available LLM to date.

item.title: Llama 3 is not very censored
item.description: Compared to Llama 2, Llama 3 feels much less censored. Meta has substantially lowered false refusal rates. Llama 3 will refuse less than 1/3 of the prompts previously refused by Llama 2.

item.title: Google announces Firebase Genkit with Ollama support
item.description: At Google IO 2024, Google announced Ollama support in Firebase Genkit, a new open-source framework for developers to build, deploy and monitor production-ready AI-powered apps.

item.title: An entirely open-source AI code assistant inside your editor
item.description: Continue enables you to easily create your own coding assistant directly inside Visual Studio Code and JetBrains with open-source LLMs.

item.title: Google Gemma 2
item.description: Gemma 2 is now available on Ollama in 3 sizes - 2B, 9B and 27B.

item.title: Tool support
item.description: Ollama now supports tool calling with popular models such as Llama 3.1. This enables a model to answer a given prompt using tool(s) it knows about, making it possible for models to perform more complex tasks or interact with the outside world.

item.title: Reduce hallucinations with Bespoke-Minicheck
item.description: Bespoke-Minicheck is a new grounded factuality checking model developed by Bespoke Labs that is now available in Ollama. It can fact-check responses generated by other models to detect and reduce hallucinations.

item.title: Llama 3.2 goes small and multimodal
item.description: Ollama partners with Meta to bring Llama 3.2 to Ollama.

item.title: IBM Granite 3.0 models
item.description: Ollama partners with IBM to bring Granite 3.0 models to Ollama.

item.title: Llama 3.2 Vision
item.description: Llama 3.2 Vision 11B and 90B models are now available in Ollama.

item.title: Ollama Python library 0.4 with function calling improvements
item.description: With Ollama Python library version 0.4, functions can now be provided as tools. The library now also has full typing support and new examples have been added.

item.title: Structured outputs
item.description: Ollama now supports structured outputs making it possible to constrain a model's output to a specific format defined by a JSON schema. The Ollama Python and JavaScript libraries have been updated to support structured outputs.

item.title: Minions: where local and cloud LLMs meet
item.description: Avanika Narayan, Dan Biderman, and Sabri Eyuboglu from Christopher Ré's Stanford Hazy Research lab, along with Avner May, Scott Linderman, James Zou, have developed a way to shift a substantial portion of LLM workloads to consumer devices by having small on-device models (such as Llama 3.2 with Ollama) collaborate with larger models in the cloud (such as GPT-4o).

item.title: Ollama's new engine for multimodal models
item.description: Ollama now supports new multimodal models with its new engine.

item.title: Streaming responses with tool calling
item.description: Ollama now supports streaming responses with tool calling. This enables all chat applications to stream content and also call tools in real time.

item.title: Thinking
item.description: Ollama now has the ability to enable or disable thinking. This gives users the flexibility to choose the model’s thinking behavior for different applications and use cases.

item.title: Secure Minions: private collaboration between Ollama and frontier models
item.description: Secure Minions is a secure protocol built by Stanford's Hazy Research lab to allow encrypted local-remote communication.

item.title: Ollama's new app
item.description: Ollama's new app is now available for macOS and Windows.

item.title: OpenAI gpt-oss
item.description: Ollama partners with OpenAI to bring gpt-oss to Ollama and its community.

item.title: Cloud models
item.description: Cloud models are now in preview, letting you run larger models with fast, datacenter-grade hardware. You can keep using your local tools while running larger models that wouldn’t fit on a personal computer.

item.title: New model scheduling
item.description: Ollama now includes a significantly improved model scheduling system, reducing crashes due to out of memory issues, maximizing GPU utilization and performance, especially on multi-GPU systems.

item.title: Web search
item.description: A new web search API is now available in Ollama. Ollama provides a generous free tier of web searches for individuals to use, and higher rate limits are available via Ollama’s cloud.

item.title: NVIDIA DGX Spark
item.description: The latest NVIDIA DGX Spark is here! Ollama has partnered with NVIDIA to ensure it runs fast and efficiently out-of-the-box.

item.title: Qwen3-VL
item.description: Ollama now supports Alibaba's Qwen3-VL.

item.title: New coding models & integrations
item.description: GLM-4.6 and Qwen3-coder-480B are available on Ollama’s cloud service with easy integrations to the tools you are familiar with. Qwen3-Coder-30B has been updated for faster, more reliable tool calling in Ollama’s new engine.

item.title: NVIDIA DGX Spark performance
item.description: We ran performance tests on release day firmware and an updated Ollama version to see how Ollama performs.

item.title: MiniMax M2
item.description: MiniMax M2 is now available on Ollama's cloud. It's a model built for coding and agentic workflows.

item.title: OpenAI gpt-oss-safeguard
item.description: Ollama is partnering with OpenAI and ROOST (Robust Open Online Safety Tools) to bring the latest gpt-oss-safeguard reasoning models to users for safety classification tasks. gpt-oss-safeguard models are available in two sizes: 20B and 120B, and are permissively licensed under the Apache 2.0 license.
